It’s a trap! Be careful about using the Chinese Remainder Theorem here since 6 and 10 are not coprime.

That being said, the same type of idea can be used to get a solution so long as you isolate for 0 and factor at the key step where you cannot invert a non coprime element.

question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
The conditions

\[\begin{aligned} x &\equiv 3 \mod{6}\\ x &\equiv 1 \mod{10}\end{aligned}\]

give us that there is a positive integer s such that

\[\begin{aligned} x &= 3 + 6s.\end{aligned}\]

Substituting into the second equation yields

\[\begin{aligned} 3 + 6s &\equiv 1 \mod{10}.\end{aligned}\]

Isolating for 0 gives

\[\begin{aligned} 2(3s +1)&\equiv 0 \mod{10}.\end{aligned}\]

Hence, we have that 5 must divide the term in the bracket, that is

\[\begin{aligned} 3s+1 \equiv 0 \mod{5}\end{aligned}\]

This gives

\[\begin{aligned} 3s &\equiv -1 \mod{5}.\end{aligned}\]

Multiplying both sides by 2 gives

\[\begin{aligned} s &\equiv -2 \equiv 3 \mod{5}.\end{aligned}\]

Hence \(\displaystyle s = 3 + 5t\) for some integer t. Thus,

\[\begin{aligned} x &= 3 + 6s = 3 + 6(3 + 5t) = 3 + 18 + 30t = 21 + 30t\end{aligned}\]

and hence all solutions are given by

\(\displaystyle x \equiv 21 \mod{30}\).
statement_html:
Determine all integers x that satisfy the following system of linear congruences.

\[\begin{aligned} x &\equiv 3 \mod{6}\\ x &\equiv 1 \mod{10}\end{aligned}\]
